image.altText: A frowning woman with curly blonde hair and wearing a blue shirt sits in front of an open laptop.

props.synopsis: A clinical psychologist warns that winter rain will not "wash away the worries" caused by severe drought across southern Australia.

title.children: More farmers seek mental health support as drought a 'daily rollercoaster'

image.altText: A police supplied image of three young children

props.synopsis: South Australian police are calling for information about three children under the age of three who were last seen more than two weeks ago. They are believed to be with a woman known to them.Â

title.children: SA Police has welfare concerns for three children missing for weeks

image.altText: Drone shot of water and port surrounding a steelwork factory

props.synopsis: GFG Alliance has placed its subsidiary company which formerly operated the Whyalla port into administration, saying it was left with no other option after the state government intervened in an ownership dispute over the facility.

title.children: GFG puts Whyalla port company into administration after 'severe impact' on revenue

image.altText: An ambulance driving past the Royal Adelaide Hospital

props.synopsis: Ambulance ramping hours in South Australia rose to their third-highest level on record in May, with the latest surge prompting concerns about a long winter ahead.

title.children: SA ambulance ramping rising again, prompting 'grave concerns' for winter

image.altText: Ken Hinkley walks off Manuka Oval.

props.synopsis: GWS fall short in Canberra without injured skipper Toby Greene, putting their top-eight spot in jeopardy as the Power grab vital win on the road for coach Ken Hinkley.

title.children: Hinkley bristles when questioned about Power's finals hopes

image.altText: Aerial view of trees and water in Lake Eyre.

props.synopsis: Lake Eyre being full is not just a once-in-a-lifetime moment it's also a chance for outback towns to feast on tourism.

title.children: Why the sheer scale of Lake Eyre 'makes you feel insignificant'

image.altText: lady sitting on orange couch smiling at camera

props.synopsis: When Geranium Primary School was forced to close its doors due to dwindling enrolment numbers, it shut a century-old chapter for the tiny town. But then one former teacher with big dreams stepped in to help her town blossom again.

title.children: Town of 80 buys old primary school for $1.10 and turns it into op shop

image.altText: The interior of a large industrial plant

props.synopsis: The South Australian government has set aside another $384 million to keep the Whyalla steelworks running next financial year â doubling the amount already allocated to keep the plant operating during administration.

title.children: $384m contingency to keep Whyalla steelworks afloat

image.altText: Stephen Mullighan holds the 2025 SA state budget papers as he stands oustide with tall city buildings behind him

props.synopsis: Despite saying South Australia doesn't have a law and order problem, the Malinauskas government has delivered a budget which spruiks funding for law and order, including a $172 million spend to increase the state's police force.

title.children: The curious case of South Australia's law and order budget

image.altText: The Milky Way shines brightly above a country town during a blackout.

props.synopsis: Electricity companies that breach their licenses should be forced to compensate customers, an inquiry into a prolonged blackout in Far West New South Wales has found.

title.children: Power companies should pay compensation for blackouts, report finds

image.altText: Image of man with serious face and black shirt

props.synopsis: A man who "savagely" attacked and stabbed former Bachelorette contestant Paddy Colliar, who was working as a topless waiter at a 60th birthday party, has been jailed for at least four years.

title.children: Man jailed for four years over stabbing of 'good Samaritan' former reality TV contestant

image.altText: Forestry in SA's south-east

props.synopsis: As Australia looks to meet housing construction targets, companies in SA and Victoria's Green Triangle are investing more heavily in softwood timber.

title.children: Housing demand drives forestry companies' shift from blue gum to pine

image.altText: A young girl in a white dress.

props.synopsis: Life seemed perfect for Lauren Flanigan and her young daughter, Sophia Rose â until the day the three-year-old with the beaming smile was allegedly murdered by her mother.

title.children: How a picture-perfect family was shattered by a senseless tragedy

image.altText: A protest sign sits next to a council sign.

props.synopsis: Port Lincoln residents push back against a proposal from their council to develop five parcels of land for housing.

title.children: Residents say council push to develop green space 'concerning'

image.altText: John Griffin

props.synopsis: John Edward Tilly Griffin has been jailed for more than nine years for the manslaughter of Gary Robinson at Port Neill in September 2023, in which Mr Robinson was left covered in shampoo, sprinkles and birdseed.

title.children: Killer inflicted 'blows of considerable force' before throwing sprinkles on victim

image.altText: A full street with people marching with flags and signs . one says liberation freedom restitution.

props.synopsis: Mr White died last Tuesday after he was restrained by off-duty officers on the floor of a Coles supermarket in Alice Springs.

title.children: 'We ask for justice': Brisbane, Sydney rallies over death of Kumanjayi White

image.altText: James Paterson addresses the media at parliament house

props.synopsis: The Coalition remains committed to its defence spending target of 3 per cent of gross domestic product by the end of the decade, as Shadow Finance Minister James Paterson suggested the opposition would be open to considering broader tax reform.Â

title.children: Coalition sticks to defence spending pledge but won't say how it'll pay for it

image.altText: Dean Winter standing in the chamber.

props.synopsis: The leaders of both of Tasmania's major political parties double down on their support for the proposed Macquarie Point stadium as an early election appears likely.

title.children: 'Not giving it up for anything': Tasmanian Labor leader firm on stadium

image.altText: A grand piano on a orange and green background

props.synopsis: Tens of thousands of Australians have cast their votes in the 2025 Classic 100: Piano. Join us as we countdown to #1.

title.children: The Classic 100: Piano top 10 has begun but who will be #1 on the countdown?

image.altText: A composite photo of Victorian opposition leader John Pesutto and former Liberal MP Moira Deeming.Â

props.synopsis: So much of politics is the art of compromise. It's an art form the Victorian Liberals are unwilling to practice as the party once again rips itself apart over the fate of former leader John Pesutto.

title.children: As John Pesutto faces bankruptcy, the Victorian Liberals can't compromise

image.altText: A boy smiles as hit sits with other students at desks in a makeshift classroom in Gaza.

props.synopsis: With many of Gaza's schools damaged, destroyed or turned into shelters, makeshift classrooms have been set up in tents for the few children who can continue their education amidst the ongoing war.

title.children: With schools destroyed or used as shelter, many Gazan kids learn in tents

image.altText: Pine trees line a hill next to a river with mountains in the distance.

props.synopsis: The US president plans to open up fossil fuel extraction in the Alaskan wilderness but big oil and gas have not exactly been champing at the bit.

title.children: Trump loves Alaska oil plans but critics urge him to 'think, baby, think'

image.altText: Black smoking brick building with some floors collapsed in.

props.synopsis: Two waves of Russian attacks targeting the Ukrainian city of Kharkiv kill at least four, injuring more, as hopes of peace dim.

title.children: Key Ukraine city hit by 'most powerful attack' since start of war

image.altText: Sir David Attenborough 'appalled' about human impact on ocean floor

props.synopsis: The 99-year-old documentarian tells the heir to the British throne he hopes his latest film helps create awareness about the state of destruction in underwater environments.Â

title.children: David Attenborough tells Prince William of 'unspeakable' human impact on oceans

image.altText: School girls carry signs including 'Cool People don't deserve a warm planet', students march behind them.

props.synopsis: Fossil fuels are warming the planet. Liberal democracy is under attack. Does Australia's government understand what's happening?Â

title.children: The planet warms, liberal democracy is attacked: Does the government care?

image.altText: A man standing in front of a house.

props.synopsis: Don James is the "talk of the town" after his extraordinary fight with a kangaroo, and learns a valuable lesson about how stressed animals can react after significant disruption to their habitats.

title.children: Man survives fight with stressed roo by throwing 'backward elbows'

image.altText: Coco Gauf kisses the French Open trophy, with orange clay court in the background

props.synopsis: Coco Gauff continues a spectacular season for American women at the grand slams, battling from a set down to topple world number one Aryna Sabalenka in the French Open final.

title.children: Gauff dedicates French Open win to 'Americans who look like me'

image.altText: Close-up of a farmerâs hand holding freshly harvested rice grains before processing at the new mill.

props.synopsis: Rice farmers have opened a $10 million mill, breaking a century-long monopoly and positioning themselves to process and sell different varieties.

title.children: How a group of rice growers funded and built their own mill

image.altText: A white middle-aged couple sitting together, smiling, at a timber dining table, a mantle holding ceramic objects behind them

props.synopsis: Three years after the sudden death of her husband, author Geraldine Brooks retreated to Flinders Island to do the work of grief.

title.children: Why Geraldine Brooks went to Flinders Island to mourn her husband

image.altText: A blonde politician sitting on a chair for a photo.

props.synopsis: The Canberra Liberals leader says coercive control stripped power, freedom and independence from the two women closest to her.

title.children: Leanne Castley's plea to outlaw coercive control is painfully personal

image.altText: A boy wearing black and a traditional waistmat walks between two windows shaped like a crucifix at a church.

props.synopsis: Tonga is so serious about the Sabbath that it banned most Sunday trading. Now the king and police are urging people to keep the day holy.

title.children: Tonga strictly keeps the Sabbath. Some say it's gone too far

image.altText: A young Thai man looks towards the camera.

props.synopsis: Pinta Nattapong, 35, was working in Israel as a farm worker when he was kidnapped from Kibbutz Nir Oz and killed in captivity shortly afterwards, according to the Israeli government.

title.children: Israel retrieves body of Thai hostage kidnapped during October 7 attacks

image.altText: Three different polaroid images of the same young girl

props.synopsis: Police confirm they have discovered human remains near the Good Night National Park near Gin Gin.

title.children: Police confirm human remains found in search for missing teen Pheobe Bishop

image.altText: Peter Luck standing on the outside of his floating caravan he built.

props.synopsis: A cancer diagnosis led Peter Luck to build a houseboat that he and his wife are now touring the waterways of Australia in.Â

title.children: Cancer diagnosis prompts WA man to build a floating caravan
